channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #181 - Pull, Request and Release!
item.description: The CPAN PR challenge is gathering heat as patches begin to appear and blog entries to surface. Catalyst sees another release, the plans for the new Test-Simple are going forward, and there is even some hopeful movements on the Perl 6 front. There is no way to know if it's going to be indicative of the full year, but January sure is busy. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: London Perl Jobs Mailing List
item.description: The old London Perl Jobs mailing list is going down. Dave Cross, however, has set up a replacement, ready to take on the torch.

item.title: Can you provide an x/y Point class in other languages?
item.description: Ovid needs you! He's crafting a Perl 6 presentation, and as a comparative exercise, he needs to have implementations of the classic Point class written in different languages.

item.title: Test-Simple, Test-More, and Test-Builder. What is breaking? Should I be scared?
item.description: So there is this new release of Test-Simple coming down the pipe. Considering that this is a linchpin modules of the Perl testing ecosystem, what exactly does it entail?

item.title: MetaCPAN Welcomes Panopta as a Sponsor
item.description: The CPAN web portals, search.cpan.org and metacpan, are incredibly important for our day-to-day work, and it's easy to forget that their continued existence is usually fueled by the unrelentless dedication of a few volunteers and a budget that would make shoe strings seem opulent. In that optic, a new sponsor is always reason to celebrate. Huzzah for Panopta!

item.title: Serializers for Perl: when to use what
item.description: YAML, JSON, Serial, so many serializers to choose from... Aristotle offers a brief overview of the serializing landscape, and provide guidance on when to use the different players in the field.

item.title: Preliminary Task List for the next Perl Catalyst Development Cycle "Australorp"
item.description: A new release done and shipped. But no rest for the wicked: the next development cycle already starts for Catalyst. John shares with us its battleplan.

item.title: Keeping Perl Classy
item.description: Rose interviewed haarg on Perl in general, and its OO aspect in particular.

item.title: How to make your first contribution to CPAN - the first steps
item.description: Contributing to a CPAN module is more than a fork and a pull request. As he attacks his first PR mission, Nitish walks us through the finer details of submitting a change to a Perl distribution.

item.title: What to do with a CPAN distribution
item.description: For the participants of the CPAN PR challenge, Neil reviews what can be done with the distribution that lands in your laps.

item.title: Always do pull requests in branches
item.description: Neil discusses the etiquette (and good sense) of making small, well-isolated, easy to manage branches when submitting pull requests.

item.title: CPAN Pull Request Challenge for January: DateTime::Format::Epoch
item.description: Michiel Beijen got assigned DateTime::Format::Epoch for January. How did he improve on that elder module? By adding NTP support!

item.title: Downloading Criminal podcast episodes
item.description: No, Sawyer is not going full black-hat on us. He's merely going through the exercise of writing a script that downloads all the episodes of this new podcast he found.

item.title: Fancy Matching of Delimited Text
item.description: Want to match delimited text, but Text::Balanced and Regexp::Common aren't good enough for the job? Be happy, for there is a new Marpa-based solution in town.

item.title: Awesome Perl
item.description: Not an article, but rather a list of want the curator considers awesome Perl libraries and frameworks.

item.title: Getting Choosy
item.description: For the interactive scripts running on MacOS, a new release of Mac::Choose is out, now offering additional drop-down shininess.

item.title: A Higher Order Idea stolen from Ramda.js
item.description: Dave saw something neat in Ramda.js, and checked out how easy it'd be to port the idea in Perl-space.

item.title: The Hills Have Multi-Faceted Eyes
item.description: Yanick ventured in his laboratory and spent a few hours stitching together a creature made of InfluxDB, Grafana and Bread::Board.

item.title: Metaprogramming HTML::FormHandler
item.description: Web forms are a pain. Domm tries to reduce the overall amount of tedium via an intake of meta-programming. Smart move, or terrible mistake? You be the judge.

item.title: Extracting from HTML with Mojo::DOM
item.description: Mojolicious comes with a lot of snazzy tools to retrieve and manipulate web content. brian demonstrates.

item.title: Grant Reports for December
item.description: Makoto reports on the Perl foundation grants for December. Inline::C/CPP as well as a new Perl::Lint are two improvements that should make people happy.

item.title: 2015.01 Get ready to Party!
item.description: Will 2015 be the year Christmas will come? It's way too early to say -- first, let's see about Easters -- but things are nonetheless stirring in the Perl 6 world.

item.title: Timestamp and elapsed time in Perl 6
item.description: Perl 6 has two separate functions fetching the time since the epoch and they return different results. As of today they are 35 seconds apart.

item.title: CPAN great modules released last week
How to get the size of a file in Perl
item.description: Using -s is simple, but looks strange for people not yet familiar with it. There are other, more readable ways to fetch the size of a file.
